reviews.text: In many ways Soderbergh is spoofing his own “Ocean’s” trilogy and has a lot of fun doing it. You can’t help but notice similarities in the two story structures, but “Logan Lucky” adds its own unique twist and is by far the broader comedy.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: It's funny, it's fun, it's incredibly well acted and Soderbergh creates a really immaculate atmosphere around the characters. A really enjoyable movie. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Victor Pineyro

reviews.text: Logan Lucky doesn’t crackle like some of Soderbergh’s previous heist films, ... but it does operate with the kind of low hum of an expertly crafted engine.
reviews.author: Fletcher Powell

reviews.text: Logan Lucky has been given Soderbergh's dependable, accessible, but also perceptive touch.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is both a portrait of working-class America and a clever bit of wish-fulfillment in which a fundamentally broken but self-perpetuating system is put in its place to the benefit of those in need.
reviews.author: Frederick Blichert

reviews.text: Thoroughly satisfying popcorn fodder.
reviews.author: Alex Behan

reviews.text: [Channing Tatum and Adam Driver] show impeccable comedy chops in this hilarious heist caper. But Daniel Craig is the MVP, with a performance that has to be seen to be believed.
reviews.author: Charlotte Harrison

reviews.text: Soderbergh is perhaps the starkest example of the contemporary non-committal filmmaker, someone unable or unwilling to adopt an important stance toward political and historical questions.
reviews.author: David Walsh

reviews.text: It would have been far more entertaining if the line "Based on a true story" had opened the picture.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: Logan Lucky represents a welcomed return for Steven Soderbergh.
reviews.author: Kelechi Ehenulo

reviews.text: Soderbergh knows how to develop good characters and maximise the talent at his disposal. Logan Lucky is a brilliant example of just that. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ricardo Gallegos

reviews.text: Soderbergh's prowess has devised a heist film that is enjoyed until the credits end. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: Easily one of the funniest things you'll see this year, but it moves so far beyond simply trying to make us laugh that you may have to watch it a few times to understand how beautifully subversive Soderbergh is in fleshing out his characters.
reviews.author: Steven Prokopy

reviews.text: Logan Lucky blends humor as well as excitement, sans the edginess you may expect in a Soderbergh picture.
reviews.author: Wendy Shreve

reviews.text: The story itself doesn't matter, and in fact, has never really mattered. It's all about how the story is told. Here, we have a cheerful and frequently funny caper that feels like a tall tale told among friends having a few drinks.
reviews.author: Tim Brennan

reviews.text: It probably goes without saying that the photography and editing are beyond reproach, but I'm going to say it anyway. Logan Lucky is a ruthlessly designed and executed entertainment machine, but its obvious virtues may obscure its depth.
reviews.author: Chris McCoy

reviews.text: podcast review
reviews.author: Julian Lytle

reviews.text: Along with the amusing characters and straightforward plot, Logan Lucky is pure entertainment.
reviews.author: Katie Smith-Wong

reviews.text: Don't examine the plot to terribly closely, just enjoy the hammy accents, the celebration of family, the clever plot twists, and the unexpected casting.
reviews.author: Leslie Combemale

reviews.text: Logan Lucky leaves you on the edge of your seat in anticipation, eager to discover what outcome or comedic antic is around the next left turn.
reviews.author: Almir Omerspahic

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is chock full of some tasty smart crackers.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is pure redneck genius and Daniel Craig delivers an absurdly awesome performance that is one of the most memorably comical of his career.
reviews.author: Chris Sawin

reviews.text: Lucky Logan comes with a twist, plenty of spirit and is gratifying in its own way.
reviews.author: Udita Jhunjhunwala

reviews.text: A bright and light robbery movie that shows it has a heart beating inside; made by the hand of a teacher who has nothing to prove. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Loser

reviews.text: It is a good entertainment that uses the apparent idiocy to build a story much smarter than it seems at a first glance. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mikel Zorrilla

reviews.text: Logan Lucky feels like a movie that [Steven] Soderbergh just couldn't decide what he wanted be. It has moments of more ridiculous humor that pokes fun at its subjects, then moments that tries to pay respect to them.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: The treatment of the southern characters ranges from insensitive to cartoonish.
reviews.author: Josh Long

reviews.text: There are precious few characters who don't look and sound like they just got back from molesting Ned Beatty alongside the Georgia river. But the movie somewhat works thanks to a solid second half and some sharp performances.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Writer Rebecca Blunt and director Steven Soderbergh dared to finally answer the long-pondered question: "What if Ocean's 11 had 1000% more camouflage pants?"
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: Disarmingly tender in the home stretch, turning into a keen and well developed take on the human quest for respect and dignity.
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: There are some great laughs, and it spends most of its run-time upending your expectations in a good way.
reviews.author: Kaitlyn Booth

reviews.text: Logan Lucky 's tires may wear thin from time to time, but its comedy, performances, and high-octane energy keep it in the race. There's simply too much fun to be had for the film to be lost in the late-summer shuffle.
reviews.author: Preston Barta

reviews.text: Despite the overall impressive filmmaking though, there are a few subplots that aren't handled quite as smoothly as the main arc.
reviews.author: Sameen Amer

reviews.text: The actors all sell it and the script kept me laughing so it worked.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: The joy is in watching the pieces all fall into place, made all the sweeter thanks to a crackling screenplay by the possibly fictional Rebecca Blunt and a cast that's firing on all cylinders.
reviews.author: Phil W. Bayles

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is not a film that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Rather, watch it reclined and relaxed, it's a heist film with a heart.
reviews.author: Deborah Cornelious

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is a fantastic time at the movies, a fast-paced film that is an outstanding example of the sort of high-concept, high-quality popcorn cinema that Steven Soderbergh makes so very well.
reviews.author: Allen Adams

reviews.text: What made Soderbergh's previous heist films so enjoyable was the sense that they were meticulously constructed...Logan Lucky...feels like a cheap knockoff.
reviews.author: Marisa Carpico

reviews.text: A witty script and fantastic performances, particularly from a nearly-unrecognisable Daniel Craig, make this more than just another crime caper.
reviews.author: Jennifer Heaton

reviews.text: Ocean's Eleven by way of Ricky Bobby.
reviews.author: Matt Oakes

reviews.text: That these seemingly dim dudes with cartoonish Southern accents, a matter-of-fact grounding in the world of NASCAR, county fairs, John Denver and child beauty pageants are actually smarter than we assume isn't a "gag" but a key part of the story.
reviews.author: Bob Chipman

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is triumphant return, a crowd-pleasing heist movie that is funny, thrilling, and just so damn cool.
reviews.author: Sean Mulvihill

reviews.text: A sharp-looking vehicle, even if there's not much going on under the hood.
reviews.author: Daniel Barnes

reviews.text: The formula succeeds because the final product is an entertaining ride as similar to [the Ocean's trilogy's] concept as it is dissimilar in environment.
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: It's a decent comeback for Soderbergh, though not one that fires on all cylinders.
reviews.author: Tomas Trussow

reviews.text: Funny, creative, and the refreshing heist movie of its genre since "Ant-Man", "Logan Lucky" is an entertaining romp from beginning to end.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: Yes haw! Steven Soderbergh is back with an end of summer hayride of a film that will have you howling.
reviews.author: Glynis Costin

reviews.text: Logan Lucky doesn't try to be something it's not and with its somewhat charming nature, it's a heist film that knows how to keep it light without losing its edge.
reviews.author: Mae Abdulbaki

reviews.text: This is that rare breed of subtle comedy that engages your heart, mind and funny bone, all at the same time.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: It's a heist movie, so we are still cheering for criminal behavior, but it is positively old-fashioned in its warm-hearted generosity toward its characters and by extension its viewers.
reviews.author: Kathryn Reklis

reviews.text: Content to unfold seamlessly, indulging in the pleasures of listening to people banter. It moves forward at a gleeful pace, creating a slap-happy momentum reminiscent of the careening madness found in the best 1940s-era screwball comedies.
reviews.author: Glenn Heath Jr.

reviews.text: This is just not as great as it could have been and it is so deeply frustrating given what a trailblazer Steven Soderbergh has been over the past 20 years.
reviews.author: Rosalynn Try-Hane

reviews.text: It's a guilty pleasure, but it's definitely a pleasure.
reviews.author: Steve Murray

reviews.text: As we get to know the characters, it becomes clear that something deeper is going on.
reviews.author: Megan Basham

reviews.text: Perhaps the biggest surprise comes from the fact that Soderbergh and his cast make the brothers sympathetic, rather than merely treating them with condescension. Tatum and Driver portray Jimmy and Clyde with an underlying sense of dignity.
reviews.author: Carl Kozlowski

reviews.text: Soderbergh has made an indie movie the way he wanted to, on his terms, and the result shows the success of this method.
reviews.author: Joseph Walsh

reviews.text: There is no doubting that Logan Lucky has a big heart and tries its hardest to be endearing, but it falls a couple of rednecks short of a Lynyrd Skynyrd concert.
reviews.author: Toby Woollaston

reviews.text: With a quartet of committed and super-fun performances from Channing Tatum, Adam Driver, Riley Keough, and Daniel Craig, it's tough not to be incredibly thankful to have Steven Soderbergh back doing his thing.
reviews.author: Joe Reid

reviews.text: Logan Lucky shows Soderbergh operating modestly with optimum skill.
reviews.author: Jeremy Carr

reviews.text: The film has a comfortable shaggy feel, even as it unspools a fairly tight heist.
reviews.author: Al Hoff

reviews.text: ... the folksy, loping, rural Southern answer to the snappy, swinging, showbiz flair of Soderbergh's Ocean's 11 and sequels.
reviews.author: Sean Axmaker

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is a rarity on multiple levels, just as remarkable as what the film comes to call "the Hillbilly Heist."
reviews.author: Karen Han

reviews.text: The Logan family may have had a curse on them, but this winning outing from returning director Steven Soderbergh has lifted it; Logan Lucky is one madcap heist flick that ranks up there with the best of them.
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: The auteur who was smart enough to rethink the classic heist movie has returned with a turbocharged gasser, Logan Lucky, that once again puts him in the pole position.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: The film is a breezy, undemanding romp, a nice respite from what's in theaters now.
reviews.author: Rob Lowman

reviews.text: ...a very funny heist caper.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: Only Craig's turn really leaves an impression, and you're left with the feeling that, for all its brio, Logan Lucky doesn't amount to a hill of beans, as they say in those parts.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: [Steven Soderbergh] is back in Hollywood with Logan Lucky, one of the best films of his career. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nazareno Brega

reviews.text: Like all his film's, this one has a homebrew flavour of Soderbergh's backyard of anti-studio film development. That makes it both fresh and fantastic.
reviews.author: Rachit Gupta

reviews.text: This is a fun film. These characters aren't the sharpest tools in the shed and they make a few mistakes along the way.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: Logan Lucky follows the classic structure of the Heist Movies. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Alberto Sáez Villarino

reviews.text: Even if it doesn't raise the stakes of the genre, there's enough potential to turn this funny and smartly written caper into another entertaining Soderbergh franchise.
reviews.author: Neil Soans

reviews.text: You'll certainly find bracingly funny moments scattered throughout an amusing tale that benefits with the sprightly insouciance adopted by a filmmaker who has nothing to prove.
reviews.author: Filipe Freitas

reviews.text: Soderbergh has returned in top form to prescribe an entertaining and very enjoyable exhibition of himself. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Martínez

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is a fun heist flick with a satisfyingly smart twist, too, full of great performances and deadpan humor and it will eventually find an audience, even if it's not a box office smash. Movies this fun and well-made always do.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: Welcome back, Steven.
reviews.author: Jordan Ruimy

reviews.text: ... the redneck answer to Ocean's Eleven (2001), as suggested one of the many winks of the film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jordi Costa

reviews.text: Lively, cunning and witty. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yago García

reviews.text: A hilarious and crazy parody that takes its raw material very seriously and moves between the ridiculously sublime to give the spectator memorable moments. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Paula Arantzazu Ruiz

reviews.text: While Logan Lucky falls strictly into the category of popcorn entertainment, that doesn't make it any less worthy of praise.
reviews.author: Lee Jutton

reviews.text: Not so much a slow burner as a damp squib.
reviews.author: Matthew Bond

reviews.text: It is the cleanest heist film I have ever seen.
reviews.author: Sr. Rose Pacatte

reviews.text: ... Logan Lucky is dazzlingly entertaining, while its surprising core ultimately gives way to an impact that is much more profound and poignant than you expect it to be.
reviews.author: Gregory Wakeman

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is sensational, the fact it stole my heart away with seemingly so little effort whatsoever the greatest heist of them all.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: A clever, goofy and a thoroughly entertaining ride.
reviews.author: Marija Djurovic

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is delightful entertainment.
reviews.author: Joanne Soh

reviews.text: Soderbergh raises clumsy and absurd moments to keep the mood, wrapped in country-style musical atmospheres like John Denver and Creedence Clearwater Revival. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Fernando Galván

reviews.text: A flighty shrimp and grits caper that willfully evokes the best - and a little of the worst - of [Soderbergh's] billion dollar-grossing [Ocean's] trilogy.
reviews.author: J. Olson

reviews.text: Need escape? Logan Lucky is for you.
reviews.author: Diane Pershing

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is intelligent comedy presented through absolute stupidity, and I feel lucky to have watched it.
reviews.author: Keeva Stratton

reviews.text: One of the most pure fun times I've had at the movies this year.
reviews.author: Matt Patches

reviews.text: Directed by Steven Soderberg, the film is intended as a backhander to the director's own Ocean's 11 trilogy, which were all glossy, hi-tech, largely unfunny and totally lacking in ideas. Logan Lucky certainly provides an entertaining counter punch.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: ...  Logan Lucky  speeds and cruises like the freshest Ford Mustang. It shifts and drifts without any sign of choking.
reviews.author: Jon Winkler

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is emblematic of the classic 1980s Hollywood blockbuster: it is great fun while it lasts, but you will forget it soon after.
reviews.author: Aakash Karkare

reviews.text: [Logan Lucky] is packed with deadpan humour, speedway action and a myriad twists.
reviews.author: Rashid Irani

reviews.text: Stylish but shallow, this could be the director's next franchise, along with Eleven and Magic Mike.
reviews.author: John Lui

reviews.text: ...the movie, despite its raft of appealing attributes, comes off as a forgettable caper that could (and should) have been so much better.
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: If nothing else, see the film for Craig's portrayal of pure larcenous joy. It is a thing of beauty, as white hot as his livid blue eyes.
reviews.author: Dorothy Woodend

reviews.text: Come for the zippy comedy about ordinary people mastering their own destinies. Stay for the entertaining filmmaking masterclass.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: A singular film-maker returns from a cinematic sabbatical in qualified triumph. We're lucky to have him.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: What could go wrong? Rather a lot and the most enjoyable parts of. Soderbergh's smartly written film involve the negotiations and shared worries of the amateurish but thoroughly lovable gang.
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: He's made great movies in both categories, but with Logan Lucky, Soderbergh the studio-movie entertainer and Soderbergh the clinical, experimental stylist fully merge.
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: Logan Lucky hums and purrs along like an Xfinity Ford Mustang, although, once the smoke clears, you may find yourself wondering if you've been watching a film about anything.
reviews.author: Tom Shone

reviews.text: Soderbergh films the movie with swing, relishing the overlapping and intertwining strands of the complex plot, the brightly lit personalities of the characters it involves, and the magnificently conceived, essential tiny details ...
reviews.author: Richard Brody

reviews.text: Though the prison break and heist scenes are slickly and efficiently staged, the film's great strength is its good nature.
reviews.author: Simran Hans

reviews.text: Clever, wildly entertaining West Virginia-set heist comedy-a terrific entertainment described as an "Ocean's 7-Eleven" inside the movie itself...warmly empathetic embrace of its economically dismissed characters... wears its kindly politics on its sleeve
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: It would be a fabulously funny and endlessly entertaining summer treat no matter who was making it - though it's hard to imagine anyone making it as well as Soderbergh.
reviews.author: Jason Bailey

reviews.text: Here is a likable, sometimes uproarious, movie in which every actor comes up with something funny. We've got a lot of Southern gothics, but very few southern Ealing comedies.
reviews.author: Richard von Busack

reviews.text: While it's overlong and sometimes disjointed, this heist flick delivers genuinely likable characters, winning performances and solid laughs.
reviews.author: Margot Harrison

reviews.text: The charm of this film is not the heist, which is ridiculously complicated and improbable, but in its combination of quirky, often very funny, characters and the entirely earnest way the actors play these characters.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh returns to the big screen after a self-imposed "retirement" with a movie that's very much in the vein of his Ocean's trilogy but pulpier and quirkier -- and tons of fun.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Fun enough and diverting enough while you're in the middle of it, but hints of something much richer and more satisfying dangle just out of its reach.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: Daniel Craig displays a gift for character comedy that suggests he'll have plenty of new and exciting avenues to explore in his post-Bond career.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: Wildly entertaining.
reviews.author: Charlotte O'Sullivan

reviews.text: Expertly made but strangely uninvolving.
reviews.author: Allan Hunter

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh returns from his self-imposed retirement with a hillbilly heist movie that has too many funny accents but not enough funny lines.
reviews.author: Jamie Dunn

reviews.text: Soderbergh directs with his trademark pace and panache, but to this he adds an obvious affection for his hapless hillbilly heroes.
reviews.author: Debra Craine

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh ... is a steady hand when it comes to these convoluted crime capers and this pleasingly unspools to reveal a plot within a plot.
reviews.author: Tim Evans

reviews.text: Not the precision near-masterpiece that Out of Sight is, nor as tight or funny as the Ocean's films, but it's certainly got all the requisite qualities [of the genial heist movie] ... goes down smooth and easy ... the jokes raise a smile [not] a laugh.
reviews.author: CJ Johnson

reviews.text: If this is the kind of eminently stylish and self-assured work that comes after taking a four-year hiatus from feature filmmaking, perhaps more directors should start looking into extended vacations as well.
reviews.author: Peter Sobczynski

reviews.text: What a fun movie.
reviews.author: Uri Klein

reviews.text: Like in the Ocean films, Soderbergh's loaded A-list goes on and on.
reviews.author: Tom Meek

reviews.text: Logan's Lucky feels like a filmmaker re-indulging a passion. It's beautifully shot, as stylish as ever, impeccably acted and typically articulate.
reviews.author: Rob Carnevale

reviews.text: Logan Lucky feels like the work of a filmmaker with nothing to prove, neither sententious seriousness of purpose nor technical knowhow.
reviews.author: Nick Pinkerton

reviews.text: A couple of clicks toward even more weirdness and Logan Lucky might have landed Soderbergh in Coen Brothers territory. Now that really would have been something to behold.
reviews.author: Ned Lannamann

reviews.text: All national and industry politics aside, Logan Lucky is a high-octane gas, a shaggy-dog story that's hard to outguess.
reviews.author: Tim Appelo

reviews.text: It's USP is that it's "a red-necked Oceans" or "a hillbilly Oceans" so, in other words, it's a riff on Oceans. Soderbergh directed the Ocean's franchise, so it is hardly a stretch for him. Or us, for that matter.
reviews.author: Deborah Ross

reviews.text: Soderbergh... remains a talented filmmaker with an instinctive gift for pacing and style. Cinephiles can rejoice that his self-imposed retirement seems to be over, even if he doesn't push himself too hard in this modest return.
reviews.author: J.R. Kinnard

reviews.text: Filled with colourful characters, crazy situations, clever camera shots and choice soundtrack cuts, Logan Lucky's beautifully layered plot features more twists and turns than a Nascar race (which admittedly isn't hard).
reviews.author: James Croot

reviews.text: Remember how panicked we all were when Soderbergh said he was retiring a few years back? Thank the film gods, there's always one last heist.
reviews.author: Max Weiss

reviews.text: With Logan Lucky, Soderbergh, one of our most inventive and unpredictable directors, just wants to have fun and bring the audience in on it. That's going to be all right with a lot of us.
reviews.author: Stephen Rebello

reviews.text: If the Ocean's Eleven movies left you with the urge to upgrade your wardrobe, Logan Lucky might inspire a day at the races.
reviews.author: Josh Terry

reviews.text: It's always supremely watchable, but rarely, if ever, commits itself to genuine jeopardy or suspense.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: We admire the cheek and chic of how it's done. We wonder quite why it was thought worth doing.
reviews.author: Nigel Andrews

reviews.text: The film's comedy is loose and generous, and its esprit de corps sneaks up on you with a soft tread.
reviews.author: Tim Robey

reviews.text: The ideal combination of grown-up concerns and childlike joy for big goofy movies.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: Logan Lucky builds to one of those impossibly complicated heists that only ever happen in movies and rather contradicts the notion that the Logans are stupid or cursed.
reviews.author: David 'Mad Dog' Bradley

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh makes entertaining, well-crafted films. Logan Lucky is no different. If you're in the mood for a heist-comedy that looks fantastic, you're not going to go wrong.
reviews.author: Dave Crewe

reviews.text: Daniel Craig steals the show.
reviews.author: Harry Guerin

reviews.text: [Logan Lucky] is not going to win him any Oscars but Soderbergh certainly appears to have recovered his zest for filmmaking.
reviews.author: Geoffrey Macnab

reviews.text: Soderbergh, back from a self-inflicted hiatus, is the perfect man to bring this Rebecca Blunt screenplay to life, utilising his experience in this sub-genre to triumphant effect.
reviews.author: Stefan Pape

reviews.text: A frolicsome rural crime thriller.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: The movie almost has enough assured touches and aromatic performances to make you overlook that the humour is generic at times and that the story suffers from not having a genuine antagonist to shake things up.
reviews.author: Craig Mathieson

reviews.text: Soderbergh's most entertaining film, since at all times on the screen you can tell that the cast is having a great time. This is contagious and compensates many times for the slow development of the plot. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is like a cheerful sing-a-long of a movie, sweeping its audience along easily, even if some of the details quickly vanish from memory.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: Soderbergh knows precisely how the formula works: likable leads, eccentric supporting characters, a complicated plan, unexpected glitches...
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: An absurd -- and absurdly funny -- cinema experience, marking a welcome return to the form by Soderbergh.
reviews.author: Annlee Ellingson

reviews.text: Lithe, lively and ludicrous, Logan Lucky is a joyful celebration of Southern culture with a generous helping of down-home whimsy.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: ...suffers from more than one kind of Southern drawl.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is like those inline tube slides at a water park: you don't worry about where you're going, because getting there is so much darned fun.
reviews.author: Karen Krizanovich

reviews.text: Soderbergh is back for real, with no signs of rust at all
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: Transposing the milieu from glitz to grits . . .it does more set an intricate heist flick in the back roads of Appalachia, it also makes a sly statement about class, culture, and our preconceived notions about those two things.
reviews.author: Andrea Chase

reviews.text: The heist is fun, but the detailed inside look at the workings of a speedway really makes Logan Lucky special.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: Soderbergh again proves his mastery at this sort of comic crime thriller.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: We're talking at least 11, 12, 13, maybe 14 players involved in robbing the Charlotte Motor Speedway. (Not that the Rube Goldbergian plot -- with the accent on rube, of course -- bears any resemblance to any of Soderbergh's trio of "Ocean's" movies).
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: Such is the merriment of the new movie, and so spirited is its pace, that you barely notice the wavering of the tone.
reviews.author: Anthony Lane

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh's amusing, escapist, 'Oceans 7-Eleven' heist is a blast!
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: A very funny heist film.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: This picture suggests a great director easing back into the feature-film game.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: Just as impressive as Logan Lucky's technical proficiency is its winning embrace of fun.
reviews.author: Michael Arbeiter

reviews.text: The podunk milieu in which Logan Lucky is set feels overstated, like a New Yorker taking a selfie in front of a Stuckey's.
reviews.author: Sean Nelson

reviews.text: Like its characters, the film has no airs about it, and simply exists to entertain viewers and it does that with plenty of aplomb and ease. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Profanity, etc. - also Available)
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is an entertaining romp powered by a smart script, strong performances across the board, and great direction.
reviews.author: Chris Agar

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is a fun and engaging caper movie directed by Steven Soderbergh.
reviews.author: Edward Johnson-Ott

reviews.text: After four years away, it's far better to have too much of a Soderbergh movie than not enough.
reviews.author: Christopher Lawrence

reviews.text: Craig manages to steal each scene he's in with his bleached hair, impeccable Southern accent and hair-trigger personality. An Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor is likely.
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is as charming and welcome as toenail fungus.
reviews.author: Rex Reed

reviews.text: It's rare that you can enter a film with full confidence that everyone involved knows what they're doing, and they're going to be excellent doing it. And in that way, Logan Lucky is the ultimate caper.
reviews.author: Rain Jokinen

reviews.text: Ocean's 7-Eleven, indeed. Amiable heist flick.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: It's good to have Soderbergh back, even if he never was really away.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh's "Logan Lucky," written by Rebecca Blunt, is a down-home heist movie that comes across like a Southern-fried variation of one of his "Ocean's" films.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: LOGAN LUCKY is a delight, peppered throughout with clever set-ups and pay-offs beset only by an over-abundance of characters.
reviews.author: Rubin Safaya

reviews.text: With a charmingly relatable cast of quirky losers...and a plot that unfolds like a Rube Goldberg construction, "Logan Lucky" is ideal summer entertainment.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: Trotting out a cast of high-caliber actors, all playing against type, Soderbergh spins a wily, joyous slice of Southern-fried outlaw adventure.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: Director Steven Soderbergh is back and firing on all cylinders in Logan Lucky, a Southern-fried heist comedy that is, like its main characters, smarter than it lets on.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: This movie does not aspire to greatness or significance; being extremely clever and thoroughly competent is the goal here.
reviews.author: Robert Horton

reviews.text: The best heist film in years.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: The script, the direction and the performances work in concert like a souped-up muscle car.
reviews.author: David Jenkins

reviews.text: Soderbergh's ace-in-the-hole has to be the young Farrah Mackenzie. When she has her big scene, no parent could resist the tug at their heart-strings. More than a heist comedy, "Logan Lucky" is an endearing father-daughter love story.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: A star-studded heist flick that calls to mind some of the eclectic director's most popular work even if it falters a bit at the end.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: A slick, smarter-than-your-average-bear heist comedy that moves and grooves with all the hallmarks of a Soderbergh caper. He's back, baby.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: The story here is clean and the characters very charming, and it doesn't fall into the trap of being smugly pleased with itself by overcomplicating matters (ahem, Ocean's Twelve).
reviews.author: Wenlei Ma

reviews.text: 'Logan Lucky' succeeds because Soderbergh shows not only respect for his characters, but reveals their hearts and souls. He gently pushes you to embrace them.
reviews.author: Bob Bloom

reviews.text: Keough is a standout and Craig is a complete hoot.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: Intelligent, fun and well executed, we could even say that the film works as a "Ocean's Fourteen". [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: When the plot stops cold for a beauty-pageant performance of exquisite purity, you'll feel like you're watching the most American film of the year.
reviews.author: Joshua Rothkopf

reviews.text: Didn't I read somewhere that Soderbergh had retired from filmmaking? This would be a perfect time for him to keep that promise.
reviews.author: Michael Heaton

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is a crackerjack heist film that strongly echoes Soderbergh's other crackerjack heist franchise, but with a uniquely downmarket and genuinely affectionate charm all its own.
reviews.author: Barry Hertz

reviews.text: Smart, clever and hilarious it is fun from start to finish line.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: It's a lark, if you can tolerate the hammy redneck accents, and confirms that Soderbergh is as agile as ever at knitting together all the moving parts of a complex heist.
reviews.author: Sara Stewart

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh, with his mysterious screenwriter Rebecca Blunt (reportedly the pseudonym of the director), and a great cast have fun in creating a twisty heist thriller with a sense of humor.
reviews.author: Robin Clifford

reviews.text: Soderbergh is in the mood for some fun, and so is a star-filled cast led by Channing Tatum, Adam Driver and Daniel Craig.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: Amusing and big-hearted, Soderbergh delivers an entertaining tale of honour among thieves.
reviews.author: Adam Fresco

reviews.text: [T]he film is tightly constructed in its plotting, while also being loose enough in its focus to appreciate what clever and relatable characters it possesses.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: [Soderbergh's] big-screen comeback, Logan Lucky, finds him taking the relatively easy option of the lighthearted heist movie, something he's always done well.
reviews.author: David Stratton

reviews.text: The whole movie is a trick, reversing our expectations at nearly every turn and casting actors in roles that they were not exactly born to play, but do so with relish.
reviews.author: David Edelstein

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh has returned from a four-year motion-picture retirement to once again show us that when it comes to crafting robberies of high stakes-even ones involving the lower classes-he remains the slickest of them all.
reviews.author: Tricia Olszewski

reviews.text: After four years of "retirement", Soderbergh shows that he is still in perfect shape. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mario Alegre

reviews.text: As sunny and implausible as an old-timer's anecdote, with a few hints at topicality that don't detract from its insouciance. It's fun for fun's sake.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: While Logan Lucky gives off the impression of a shaggy character-based comedy, such an assessment shortchanges how deliriously clever it is.
reviews.author: Dominick Suzanne-Mayer

reviews.text: Who among us predicted that Channing Tatum would become a major actor, equally adept at light-fingered comedy and low-key contemporary dramas?
reviews.author: Ken Eisner

reviews.text: . . .this Friday brings with it Logan Lucky, a southern-fried caper of virtuosic showmanship that, beneath its easygoing exterior, also succeeds at tapping into larger s...[ END HERE ]ocioeconomic concerns
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: Soderbergh's return to features is a redneck riff on his Ocean's 11, a cool breeze of summertime sweetness that restores the good name of movie escapism. Daniel Craig is off-the-chain hilarious.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: Like the best of his movies, this heist film retains its essential shagginess despite the A-list stars headlining it, and it reminds us what a nifty flair the director has for light entertainment.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: As a hotly anticipated comeback, it feels like a slightly dippy, ultimately disposable warm-up of a director whose brains, chops and judicious taste we need more than ever.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: "Logan Lucky" is his down-home version of the "Ocean's" franchise, with NASCAR instead of the Bellagio, but it's every bit as cheeky, fun and funny.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: Essentially a red-state Ocean's Eleven - a fizzy, twisty Southern-fried heist flick that's more enjoyable the less you try to dissect it.
reviews.author: Chris Nashawaty

reviews.text: Soderbergh rolls the dice with 'Logan Lucky' and comes up with a winner.
reviews.author: Roger Tennis

reviews.text: Steven Soderberg's funny, underdog heist movie is a heartfelt paean to the kinds of Southern working-class whites normally caricatured as Confederate-flag-waving racists.
reviews.author: Jason Di Rosso

reviews.text: The movie is smart and funny, though ultimately it's less noteworthy as an entertainment than as a marketing concept.
reviews.author: J. R. Jones

reviews.text: The result is a breezy, slight, Southern-flavored movie where the cast appears to be having enough fun to prove mildly infectious.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: The script's vibe recalls Soderbergh's arch, knowing "Ocean's" movies, but also evokes older pictures such as "Bank Shot" in the early '70s or "Who's Minding the Mint?" in the late '60s.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: But the best part of Logan Lucky is that from the get-go you know you're in confident hands, and whatever's about to happen, it's going to be great.
reviews.author: Alissa Wilkinson

reviews.text: A nice change of pace for Soderbergh, who, for the first time in a long time, seems genuinely interested in providing an entertaining ride.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: Perhaps "Logan Lucky" is best appreciated as a stealth commentary on tough times in America. It takes a director of Soderbergh's gifts to actually make that funny.
reviews.author: Calvin Wilson

reviews.text: If it verges on being a little too pleased with itself for its own good, that's an acceptable price to pay for something that makes you smile.
reviews.author: Kenneth Turan

reviews.text: In the very least, Hal Needham's Smokey and the Bandit films displayed a fair amount of affection amid the hamming for their shit-kicking rubes.
reviews.author: Scott Marks

reviews.text: Heartfelt felicitations to [Steven] Soderbergh on his rebirth of the cool.
reviews.author: Kimberley Jones

reviews.text: Jimmy's team is like a blue-collar mirror image of the Ocean's crew. But there's more going on here than a story about a bunch of amateurs attempting a complicated robbery.
reviews.author: Karen Gordon

reviews.text: A precision-tooled entertainment made by experts, and sometimes more than that. Watching it is like finding money in the pocket of a coat that you haven't worn in years.
reviews.author: Matt Zoller Seitz

reviews.text: The glitz and glamour of the Ocean's trilogy is in a completely different area code than Logan Lucky, but Soderbergh's latest has the same terrific camaraderie and joy as those movies.
reviews.author: Jack Giroux

reviews.text: I liked the movie - it's certainly well made, and a lot of fun - but I mostly found myself laughing at it, not with it.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: Logan Lucky reminded me most of Howard Hawks' El Dorado. It has the tossed-off, casual sophistication of an old master's late work.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: Rating Soderbergh's back catalogue is like comparing apples and oranges and tractors, but this is in his top bracket. Welcome back, Mr Soderbergh.
reviews.author: Matt Neal

reviews.text: A high-spirited hillbilly-heist caper with a dynamite, all-star ensemble cast.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: It ... feels like the director is trying to reverse-engineer one of the Coen brothers' loopier excursions and not getting every one of the pieces in order. But he comes close.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: The actors mostly lean hard on comical redneck accents, and the slow-moving plot features way too many leaps of logic.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: Quite simply, one of the most sheerly enjoyable movies of the year....we're lucky to have [Soderbergh] back.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: So warmheartedly enthusiastic, it's hard not to get swept away with this group of not-so-average Joes.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: Logan Lucky may be more of the same. But more of the same, from Soderbergh, is what more summer movies should aspire to be.
reviews.author: K. Austin Collins

reviews.text: Soderbergh smoothly glides us through this NASCAR world, emanating an old-fashioned Hal Needham vibe, but with greater character depth and extra IQ points.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: Logan Lucky lands somewhere between Magic Mike and the Ocean's trilogy. Turns out, that's one hell of a sweet spot.
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: I'm really glad Soderbergh's back doing what he does best. I didn't know how much I missed the guy.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is a hoot, a holler, a drag at times and doesn't know when to end but it's fun.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: This one offers pleasures you won't find anywhere else.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: So who really needs Logan Lucky? More to the point: Will they buy this in the South?
reviews.author: Kelly Vance

reviews.text: Soderbergh is perhaps Hollywood's finest technician, and it's a pleasure to watch him tour his Vegas act through Appalachia.
reviews.author: Chance Solem-Pfeifer

reviews.text: There's no question that the film is full of gentle, good-natured mockery of the sort of knucklehead culture that we call "redneck" but it's all very sympathetic -- more so, even, than a Jeff Foxworthy You May Be a Redneck If (filll in the blank) routine.
reviews.author: Jeff Simon

reviews.text: Some will write off Logan Lucky as one of Soderbergh's most frivolous efforts, but that would be a mistake.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is great fun and one of the most purely entertaining movies of the year.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Mr. Soderbergh revels in squareness, and in a loose self-confidence that disguises its mastery. "Logan Lucky" is a terrific movie.
reviews.author: A.O. Scott

reviews.text: I think that's a big part of what makes Logan Lucky a very fun movie: You're lost, you're lost, you're lost -- and then it all makes so much sense that you feel like you should have known what was happening all along.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: Independently financed and distributed by Soderbergh, Logan Lucky is a magnificent movie that comes disguised as a modest one. Or, as I like to call it, a Joe Bang.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: An eccentric combo of scrappy crime caper and angular redneck comedy, Logan Lucky shouldn't work anywhere near well as it does.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: Soderbergh keeps the action light and playful, and lets the cast members find their own silliness within it.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: Southern flavor, rampant goofiness and fun twangs go a long way in making director Steven Soderbergh's cinematic return such a sparkling hoot.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: For a fast and funny crime flick, Logan Lucky has plenty of grunt under the hood.
reviews.author: Travis Johnson

reviews.text: A fun and unpretentious romp that benefits from smart pacing, likeable characters and a stick-it-to-the-man undercurrent that helps keep things moving along.
reviews.author: Mike Scott

reviews.text: It's a genuine effort by talented people that never quite comes off.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: The whole thing comes together to form the best Burt Reynolds movie he never made.
reviews.author: Gary Thompson

reviews.text: The endearing charm of the characters - along with a plot that teases the audience with just enough information to keep them wondering what's next - makes Logan Lucky a winner.
reviews.author: Thaddeus McCollum

reviews.text: Sometimes, the only reason for doing anything is to have a little fun, and Soderbergh seems to be having a lot of it.
reviews.author: April Wolfe

reviews.text: Steven Soderburgh's return to the big screen may look like an Ocean's reboot a la NASCAR, but don't you go thinking this is some smart alecky snobby spin.
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: Having successfully pulled off three Danny Ocean cons, director Steven Soderbergh is looking for a new bank vault to plunder. Logan Lucky turns out to be a playfully subversive variation on the theme.
reviews.author: Vicky Roach

reviews.text: Soderbergh's here to have fun, and his mood is contagious.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: Flaws aside, it is a darn good heist, and sure to leave you with a smile on your face. We should be glad Soderbergh is back, hopefully this time for good.
reviews.author: Lindsey Bahr

reviews.text: An updated, more sophisticated take on those old Burt Reynold's seventies good ol'boy flicks.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is both a Robin Hood fantasy and a uniquely Soderberghian lark, an ensemble comedy that's simultaneously effervescent and cerebral.
reviews.author: Christopher Gray

reviews.text: If you'd like to see a blend of Ocean's 11 and Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby, then Logan Lucky is for you.
reviews.author: Scott Chitwood

reviews.text: Logan Lucky has the briskness and sheen of a professional, a man who, after years of restlessness, has become comfortable enough to simply tell a story with confidence, clarity and gusto.
reviews.author: Will Leitch

reviews.text: The snappily-edited and uber-efficient working-class caper Logan Lucky is so ephemeral, its screenwriter may not even exist.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: Fun, snappy and classically Soderbergh-ian delight with impeccable, Ocean's-like rhythms, shrewdly set against the everyday struggles of small-town America.
reviews.author: Tomris Laffly

reviews.text: Four years after his self-imposed retirement, maverick director Steven Soderbergh takes the easy way out. Or, rather, back in.
reviews.author: Mara Reinstein

reviews.text: While even the film itself cites the heist as "Ocean's 7-11", it's got a flavor and energy all its own. It's a blast from start to finish.
reviews.author: Matt Goldberg

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is a hoot. It's the sort of movie that allows you to laugh, relax and let everything wash over you... Everything is laid back - from the characters to the humour - and the payoff is delicious.
reviews.author: Louise Keller

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is a hillbilly heist caper brimming with good natured humor.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: Soderbergh shows here that the melding of mainstream storytelling and artful execution is possible.
reviews.author: Jason Guerrasio

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is easygoing entertainment that, on occasion, gently brushes up against its stiffer real-world framing. I'm not sure the film is as successful in doing that as Magic Mike is, but it still makes for an intriguingly toned film.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: With his latest directorial effort, Soderbergh has made a film that not only constantly pokes fun at its own characters and their lives, but finds a way to imbue each of them with a soul and heart along the way.
reviews.author: Alex Welch

reviews.text: Of course, there's a level of tactical sophistication to this kind of fantasy-crime scenario, but Blunt's screenplay scores many points by making the follow-through of the plan so damned pleasurable.
reviews.author: Robert Abele

reviews.text: Soderbergh executes his cine-comeback with lan, aided by winning A-team work from Tatum, Driver and Craig.
reviews.author: Kevin Harley

reviews.text: The kind of small-scale, shaggy dog story Hollywood rarely makes these days.
reviews.author: Dave Schilling

reviews.text: Logan Lucky is one country-fried hootenanny of a heist thriller that goes off with a (Joe) Bang.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: A purely auteur-driven lark slipped into an era when studios no longer want to work with directors with personality and pesky calls for final cut - a high entertainment with a handmade feel.
reviews.author: Matt Prigge

reviews.text: Logan Lucky feels a lot like Oceans 14.
reviews.author: Mike Ryan

reviews.text: This is a brilliantly constructed, whip-smart, and laugh-out-loud-funny romp from a filmmaker whose precision and craft is nearly unparalleled.
reviews.author: Drew Taylor

reviews.text: Steven Soderbergh's Logan Lucky is a high-spirited, low-down blast.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: Channing Tatum, working with Soderbergh for the fourth time, is at his sympathetic and charismatic best in Logan Lucky.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: Even if it needed one last push to make it truly exceptional, there's a lot to enjoy here. And Soderbergh once again attracts a cast it's a pleasure to spend time with.
reviews.author: Andrew Lowry

reviews.text: This is a good-times film that doesn't put on airs, dress to impress or pretend to be something it isn't. It just aims to please and does a pretty good job of it.
reviews.author: Todd McCarthy

reviews.text: This blue-collar "Ocean's Eleven" is a smooth-running, pleasantly familiar crime caper. In a movie full of cons, the greatest may be how deceptively easy Steven Soderbergh makes the whole enterprise seem.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: As the film teeters the line between ridiculous and generic screwball, the all-star cast dazzles to hilarious effect.
reviews.author: Clayton Davis

reviews.text: Logan Lucky embodies so much of what's made Steven Soderbergh that rare journeyman between arthouse and multiplex.
reviews.author: Nick Newman

reviews.text: A heist comedy that reaffirms why Soderbergh belongs behind the movie camera.
reviews.author: Oliver Whitney

reviews.text: Soderbergh returns from retirement with a silly heist movie that packs real soul.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

synopsis: West Virginia family man Jimmy Logan teams up with his one-armed brother Clyde and sister Mellie to steal money from the Charlotte Motor Speedway in North Carolina. Jimmy also recruits demolition expert Joe Bang to help them break into the track's underground system. Complications arise when a mix-up forces the crew to pull off the heist during a popular NASCAR race while also trying to dodge a relentless FBI agent.
